questions.question: If you had asked me, I …………………….. you.
questions.description: In the third conditional, we use a past perfect tense in the if-clause and would have + past participle in the main clause.

questions.question: I heard them ……………………… down the stairs.
questions.description: Hear cannot be followed by a to-infinitive.

questions.question: Phone me when you ………………………. time.
questions.description: When the main clause is in the imperative, we use a present tense to refer to the future in the subordinate clause.

questions.question: I am ……………………….. a phone call from dad at 4 pm.
questions.description: Hoping and waiting are followed by for.

questions.question: I am ………………………. for my mother to come.
You can trust him. He will never go …………………….. on his promise.
questions.description: To go back on a promise is to fail to keep it.

questions.question: The ship hit an iceberg and went …………………..
questions.description: When a ship goes down, it sinks.

questions.question: We cannot go out until the wind goes …………………………
questions.description: When wind goes down, it becomes calm again.

questions.question: You don’t need …………………….. the roof this year.
questions.description: When need is an ordinary verb, it is followed by an infinitive with to.

questions.question: He will …………………………… start coming on time.
questions.description: You cannot use must after will.

questions.question: There was ……………………… traffic that it took an hour to reach office.
questions.description: Much is unusual in affirmative clauses unless it is preceded by so.

questions.question: Good bye. See you ……………………...
questions.description: There is no preposition or article before next week, tomorrow, last year etc.
